html.p: Proposition (A). If [mathjaxinline]\dim V = n < \infty[/mathjaxinline], and [mathjaxinline]W[/mathjaxinline] is any subspace of [mathjaxinline]V[/mathjaxinline], then any linearly independent list of vectors in [mathjaxinline]W[/mathjaxinline] can be extended to form a basis of [mathjaxinline]W[/mathjaxinline].

Proposition. If [mathjaxinline]\dim V = n[/mathjaxinline], then any linearly independent list of vectors in [mathjaxinline]V[/mathjaxinline] has at most [mathjaxinline]n[/mathjaxinline] vectors. Any linearly independent list of vectors in [mathjaxinline]V[/mathjaxinline] that has exactly [mathjaxinline]n[/mathjaxinline] vectors must be a basis of [mathjaxinline]V[/mathjaxinline].

Proposition. If [mathjaxinline]\dim V = n[/mathjaxinline], then any subspace [mathjaxinline]W[/mathjaxinline] of [mathjaxinline]V[/mathjaxinline] has dimension at most [mathjaxinline]n[/mathjaxinline]. If [mathjaxinline]\dim W = n[/mathjaxinline], then [mathjaxinline]W = V[/mathjaxinline].
Proposition (B). Any finite list of vectors that spans a vector space [mathjaxinline]V[/mathjaxinline] contains a basis of [mathjaxinline]V[/mathjaxinline].

Proposition. If [mathjaxinline]\dim V = n[/mathjaxinline], then any list of vectors that spans [mathjaxinline]V[/mathjaxinline] has at least [mathjaxinline]n[/mathjaxinline] vectors. Any list of vectors that spans [mathjaxinline]V[/mathjaxinline] that has exactly [mathjaxinline]n[/mathjaxinline] vectors must be a basis of [mathjaxinline]V[/mathjaxinline].

div.p: We will first show that if a linearly independent list of vectors in [mathjaxinline]W[/mathjaxinline] is not a basis of [mathjaxinline]W[/mathjaxinline], then there is a vector in [mathjaxinline]W[/mathjaxinline] which can be added to the list maintaining linear independence.

Let [mathjaxinline]\mathcal{L} = \{ w_1; w_2; \ldots w_ k\}[/mathjaxinline] be a linearly independent list of vectors in [mathjaxinline]W[/mathjaxinline]. If [mathjaxinline]\mathcal{L}[/mathjaxinline] spans [mathjaxinline]W[/mathjaxinline], then it is a basis of [mathjaxinline]W[/mathjaxinline]. Therefore we assume that [mathjaxinline]\mathcal{L}[/mathjaxinline] is not a basis of [mathjaxinline]W[/mathjaxinline]. In particular, it does not span [mathjaxinline]W[/mathjaxinline], so we can find some vector [mathjaxinline]v\in W[/mathjaxinline] which is not a linear combination of [mathjaxinline]w_1, w_2, \ldots w_ k[/mathjaxinline]. Appending [mathjaxinline]v[/mathjaxinline] to the list [mathjaxinline]\mathcal{L}[/mathjaxinline] yields a new list [mathjaxinline]\mathcal{L'}=\{ w_1; w_2; \ldots w_ k; v\}[/mathjaxinline]; we claim that [mathjaxinline]\mathcal{L'}[/mathjaxinline] is still linearly independent.
To show this, suppose that we have a linear combination

tr.td: [mathjax]a_1w_1 + a_2w_2 + \ldots + a_ k w_ k + bv = \mathbf{0}.[/mathjax]
[mathjax]-bv = a_1w_1 + a_2w_2 + \ldots + a_ k w_ k,[/mathjax]

div.p: But we know that [mathjaxinline]v[/mathjaxinline] is not in the span of [mathjaxinline]\mathcal{L}=\{ w_1; w_2; \ldots w_ k\}[/mathjaxinline], so this is impossible. Hence [mathjaxinline]b = 0[/mathjaxinline].

However, we know that [mathjaxinline]\mathcal{L}=\{ w_1; w_2; \ldots w_ k\}[/mathjaxinline] is linearly independent, so all of the [mathjaxinline]a_ i[/mathjaxinline] must be zero as well. Therefore all of the coefficients of the original linear combination must be zero, and we have shown that the new list [mathjaxinline]\mathcal{L'}[/mathjaxinline] is linearly independent.

Therefore, we can keep adding vectors to the list, maintaining linear independence, as long as the list does not span [mathjaxinline]W[/mathjaxinline]. This procedure cannot go on forever, though, since we know that no list of more than [mathjaxinline]n[/mathjaxinline] vectors in [mathjaxinline]V[/mathjaxinline] can be linearly independent. Therefore at some point we must reach a linearly independent list which also spans [mathjaxinline]W[/mathjaxinline]; in other words, a basis of [mathjaxinline]W[/mathjaxinline]. This proves the proposition.

We will first show that if a finite, linearly dependent list of vectors spans [mathjaxinline]W[/mathjaxinline], then there is a vector in the list which can be deleted from the list so that the remaining vectors still span [mathjaxinline]W[/mathjaxinline].

Suppose that [mathjaxinline]\{ w_1; w_2; \ldots w_ k\}[/mathjaxinline] spans [mathjaxinline]W[/mathjaxinline]. If the list is linearly dependent, then one of the vectors can be written as a linear combination of the others. For ease of notation, suppose that [mathjaxinline]w_1[/mathjaxinline] is that vector, and that [mathjaxinline]w_1 = a_2w_2 + a_3w_3 +\ldots + a_ kw_ k[/mathjaxinline].

We claim that [mathjaxinline]\{ w_2; w_3; \ldots w_ k\}[/mathjaxinline] still spans [mathjaxinline]W[/mathjaxinline]. Indeed, let [mathjaxinline]u \in W[/mathjaxinline]. Since the original list spans [mathjaxinline]W[/mathjaxinline], we know that we can write [mathjaxinline]u[/mathjaxinline] as a linear combination

tr.td: [mathjax]\begin{array}{rcl} u & = & c_1(a_2w_2 + a_3w_3 +\ldots + a_ kw_ k) + c_2w_2 + \ldots + c_ kw_ k \\ & = & (c_1a_2+c_2)w_2 + \ldots + (c_1a_ k + c_ k)w_ k. \end{array}[/mathjax]

div.p: Hence [mathjaxinline]u[/mathjaxinline] can be written as a linear combination of just [mathjaxinline]\{ w_2; w_3; \ldots w_ k\} ,[/mathjaxinline] and the smaller list still spans [mathjaxinline]W[/mathjaxinline].

Thus, as long as the list remains linearly dependent, we can keep deleting vectors from the list and maintain the property that the list spans [mathjaxinline]W[/mathjaxinline]. Since the initial list is finite, however, this procedure must stop. Thus we eventually have pared the list down to a list which still spans [mathjaxinline]W[/mathjaxinline] but is also linearly independent; in other words, we obtain a basis of [mathjaxinline]W[/mathjaxinline]. This proves the proposition.
